positive.review: i Was super addicted to it during my college years. the day i submitted my final paper on non-anglo authors, and unofficially graduated just a few minutes before midnight, i recalled myself immediately occupied with nothing but this game. even on holidays and new year, i Locked myself up in my dorm and kept playing. That was cruel and critically unhealthy. i effing Like it.

soo what can I say about the game...it's a tycoon. What you can say about the tycoon is that it's very different from standard tycoons (even though I'm not a tycoon pro now), but still Two Point Campus has really put love into every detail. Just watching all the students is really funny. But well, of course I played the game to 100 percent and I really have to say that the game is very repetitive from a certain point and that's the only and also huge negative point of the game. But hey it's a tycoon, what can you expect. Anyway, the dlcs were very good. You had to fulfill certain things to unlock more properties in the level, which was not done in the base game, which I found very disappointing. You could just unlock everything with money. Whether I play the whole series...I don't know. But if you want to play a very funny tycoon. 
Go for it!!

Very fun game! Got me addicted. I do wish there were keys I could use to speed up and speed down, and that there were pre-made room templates for each map. That would improve it a lot, but it's already a great game and I highly recommend.

Fun game! But easy as hell. Nice time waster. I 3-starred the first campus before moving onto the next campus, and at this point I've completed the first 2. I'm hoping the next one will be at the least a bit challenging. I do want to keep at it to unlock more items, which just requires playing more years, but once you're set up, you're set up and you're just running down the clock waiting for the year to pass by essentially, while seeing if you hit career achievements to earn more Kudosh (special in game currency). Buy this game on a sale.
Silly little university management game, fun for a bit but gets boring quick.

I had been hesitant in the past to give this game a try because of the art style, but after an injury kept me housebound, I finally checked it out. And I'm glad I did. The management systems and the depth of the campaigns have me excited to try out the expansions once I get done with the base game, and maybe I'll even delve into the other games in the series.

Simple cartoonish management game. Just deep enough to keep you interested for and beyond the campeign while remaining on the simpler end of the genre. The DLCs are a money-grab, but not too bad of one. 

I enjoyed it, but I am crazy. So take it for what it's worth.

Solid Two Point sim game. If you like Two Point Hospital, you most likely like this game to.

Two Point Campus takes the same charm and humor from Two Point Hospital and moves it into a full college management setup. Instead of running a hospital, you are building a university from the ground up, designing classrooms, placing decorations, hiring staff, and keeping students happy enough to actually pass their classes.

The presentation is bright and friendly, with that same Two Point County humor. The courses are over the top in the best way. You can run a Knight School where students learn sword fighting, a Wizardry program, Virtual Normality, Archaeology digs, or even a full Gastronomy course where students make giant cupcakes and massive pizzas. The animations give each class personality and make the campus feel alive without turning chaotic.

The gameplay is smooth and easy to learn. You build lecture halls, libraries, dorms, clubs, and student lounges. You hire teachers, assistants, and janitors, and each one has skills that help or hurt your campus. Training staff matters a lot in this game, and it is straightforward to manage. Clicking around feels natural, and the menus are clean and simple to follow.

Student life is the heart of the game. You are not just running buildings. You have to manage friendships, clubs, dorm quality, hygiene, entertainment, relationships, and events like parties or concerts. Students have personalities, needs, and requests, and keeping them happy directly affects their grades and your campus rating. It adds a layer of strategy that feels different from the hospital version but still just as easy to understand.

Money management stays important. You need to balance tuition, building upgrades, staff salaries, and course expansions as your campus grows. Each year has its own setup phase before students arrive, so you get time to build and prepare before the pace picks up.

Every campus in the game has its own challenges. Some focus on research, others on sports, others on strict academic performance. As you earn one star at a campus, you can keep going for two and three stars if you want a bigger challenge, or move on to the next campus to unlock more buildings and courses.

Overall, Two Point Campus keeps the humor and style of Two Point Hospital but adds deeper management around students and school life. It is smooth, colorful, and full of personality. A great pick if you like building games, management sims, or anything with a relaxed but engaging pace.

My students are knights, clowns, and culinary prodigies; my janitors are philosophers; and my campus runs on chaos and vending machines. It‚Äôs less Harvard, more Hogwarts on energy drinks. üçï‚öîÔ∏èü§ì

[quote]Follow my curator page for more caffeinated campuses, scholarly nonsense, and educational chaos! ‚òïüìöüé≠

Fairly enjoyable game really. I know that a lot of people think that Hospital is better because it is fairly hard to fail at Campus, and Hospital in turn requires a lot more strategy, but I found the much more casual Campus to be more enjoyable as I'm not great at this sort of game. Felt like a lot less time being wasted on failed maps and such. 

It took just over 50 hours to both 100% the achievements and also get 3 stars in every map, and I didn't touch the challenge maps so there's likely even more playtime there if you wanted it. I think there was also a sandbox mode but I didn't touch it if there was one, as it felt like the campaign is just the right length to stay enjoyable without getting too stale.

Ran very well, with I think only one crash, and only a little bit of lagginess when you've got 300+ students and 100+ staff all romping around, most of which would happen upon editing the building or moving rooms around (as I assume it has to re-pathfind everyone).

Solid game really. Not the best, but definitely very solid. Brilliant for people who aren't that experienced with the management genre to help them get into it.

Just gone back to this game after playing a lot of Two Point Museum and it is still very enjoyable. It keeps you on your toes but is easy enough to not overwhelm. I love all the inside jokes, the animations and overall the chillness of the game. You can play it when not feeling too well and still not lose (as tested last night by me). 
I love all Two Point games and will play them for years to come! :)

Two Point Campus is a well-made campus management game that doesn‚Äôt take itself too seriously. Fans of Two Point Hospital will definitely have fun with it. The missions can get a bit repetitive, but the game still has a certain addictive quality.

[h2]Achievements[/h2]
[b]Required time:[/b] 45‚Äì60 hours
[b]Difficulty (in my opinion):[/b] 3/10
[b]DLCs required for 100%?:[/b] Yes ‚Äì 3 (Medical School, School Spirits, Space Academy)

When it comes to achievements, there‚Äôs nothing too surprising here. Just earn 3 stars in (almost) all missions, and you‚Äôll be close to 100%. Getting 3 stars isn‚Äôt very hard, just a bit time-consuming. There might be a few miscellaneous achievements left, but they can be completed fairly quickly as well. None of the achievements are missable.

Overall, it‚Äôs a relaxing and charming management game that‚Äôs perfect for completionists who don‚Äôt mind a bit of repetition.

My assumption is that most people will either really enjoy this game, or they won't, with very little in between. Perfect low-effort management/building sim to sink literal tens of hours at a time into if you, like me, are afflicted by the type of anxious-obsessive personality that both craves order and control, and yet is easily overwhelmed by the endless optimization spirals of even traditionally "cozy" games like Stardew Valley. The nature of the gameplay is admittedly repetitious, and at its core, it's basically a room-building floorplan simulator with a pretty forgiving business management sim overlaid on top- which is exactly the type of gameplay I've been craving since the death of flash, but I'm sure isn't for everyone. I also can't speak to it is an entry into the Two Points series, since this is the only game by the developers that I've played. How it might stand in comparison to the rest of the franchise, or whether it will meet the expectations of otherwise established fans, I wouldn't know. 

This game is sort of a tycoon sim, sort of a management sim, but the core resource you're managing is really physical space more than it is money. That lends to it an almost puzzle-esque style of play; you're trying to figure out the most efficient layout to fit as much as possible onto limited plots of campus land, while still maintaining functional and efficacious pathing that allows the members of your school to move around freely, attend classes, and consistently access facilities to help keep their needs met. That means bathrooms, dorms, break rooms, lecture halls, showers, vending machines, so on and on. To that end, you can tweak and restructure and move things around more or less to your hearts content, without resource limits on how many or how much of any one thing you can have. Everything also maintains value without any sort of depreciation mechanic, including the room walls and buildings themselves, so there's no consequences for changing your mind or continuously readjusting. For me, this utter leniency is *the* major draw of the game; more than any other business/management sim that I've played, this game satisfies some of my most obsessive, indecisive, and scatterbrained tendencies, without getting bogged down in min-maxing minutia or making me feel punished for not having an encyclopedic knowledge of how the game runs. In combination with the low skill floor and an apparent lack of both time limits and permanent fail states, it comes out to be something that I would affectionately term as idiot-proof, in the sense that you can more or less barely know what you're doing and as long as you follow the guiding campaign prompts of the game, you'll be successful. While this leads to a gameplay loop that a lot of people will find boring, since it denies them the satisfaction of challenge, I appreciate how it enables the player to pretty indulgently fixate on whatever part of the game they find most engaging without being a straight-up sandbox, which would be missing the sense of structure and direction that I personally find necessary to retain my interest. The overall effect is kind of soothing and about as mindless as you want it to be, like an adult coloring book or what I assume other people enjoy about building Lego sets.

Think somewhere between Prison Architect and one of the mainstream Tycoon franchise games, except easier to learn, easier to play generally, and with a somewhat tighter focus mechanically. Like a city builder game's baby brother.

This doesn't fulfill the niche of a decorating or dollhouse game, and there's no options to customize the look of the buildings themselves- each of the several base game campuses has its own predetermined theme and associated architectural style- but the outdoor object catalogue specifically is surprisingly fleshed out, and I found myself a lot more drawn to the process of designing the campus grounds than I would have initially expected. Buildings, walls, windows, doors, and entire rooms can be picked up, copied, saved as templates, and altered at will. There's also an element of human resource, wherein the staff and student body is fully populated by what are technically individuals with their own names, appearances, skills, needs, and desires, who can be minimally managed. For faculty, this involves hiring, firing, assigning job responsibilities, and training skills. Students can be expelled or assigned tutoring, and will independently form both friendships and romances between one another, which you can encourage by placing appropriate objects for them to use. There's no means of directly orchestrating interactions, however, and none of it rises to the level of what I would describe as being an actual life simulator. I also really enjoy the blocky, bright, stylized cartoon look of the graphics, especially compared to the pretty realistic look most modern 3D sims opt for, and I imagine it's part of what makes the game so performance-friendly while running what feels like a pretty expansive real-time simulation. Controls are simple and intuitive once learned, and the game can be played entirely with a mouse if you so choose, which I appreciate and mostly do.

This also isn't really a strategy game; it's just too simple. If you're looking for the more challenging, exponentially progressing, detailed and mechanic-dense style of micromanaging you see in popular factory and colony-themed management sims like Factorio or Rimworld, you'll almost certainly be disappointed by the easy difficulty and relatively limited scope. By the same token, if you're a player who's driven by narrative and characterization, you'll be left wanting by the limited customizability and interactivity of your digital populace, as well as the lack of verisimilitude for roleplaying purposes. A Sims game, this is not, aside from mild tonal similarities. That said, if you love, say, recreating floorplans for houses you found online in The Sims and repeatedly loading up the Stardew Valley Farm Planner, it's a great game. It doesn't bite off more than it can chew, in my opinion, and executes on pretty much everything you expect it to. Other than just having a kind of limited aesthetic and object catalogue which does, granted, contribute to the previously mentioned sense of repetitiveness, I have yet to find myself really wanting for something that it feels like should be there, but isn't, or like there's an element of the gameplay that isn't working like it should. For the simulation genre in particular, this is not remotely a given, whether or not one thinks it should be, and thus earns itself some pretty significant brownie points in my eyes for that alone. I think it's just plain well-made, even if it's not for everyone.

I grabbed this game on a super-deep discount, and to be completely honest, I don't know if I'd recommend it at full price (although that might just be me being very much a cheapskate), but for the five bucks or whatever I paid for it, it was so, absolutely worth it. You can probably tell from the description alone whether or not this game is for you, and if it is, I definitely would recommend at least putting it on your wishlist to be notified of the next time it's on sale. This game is like the perfect distillation of all my favorite parts of planning builds in other simulation games that I never end up executing on, so for me, it does a great job of satisfying a very particular urge. I liked it enough that I felt compelled to yap about it, at least, and that's gotta count for something, right?

I greatly enjoyed Two Point Campus. I'm not a super big fan of management games, but I enjoyed Two Point Hospital and wanted to play Two Point Campus. It's a generally fun game that's relatively easy to play. The game has a lot of animation and enjoyable visuals, but I will say I did not enjoy the music. I do wish there were more customization and objects to play with in general, but there is enough provided to get what you need done.

Campus was actually my first Two Point game. I tried it out when it was on GamePass a year or two ago and I was hooked so when I saw it on Steam recently for only around 3 dollars, I had to get it. I like it a lot more than Hospital. It feels more zanny and has more variety. And holy damn the music is amazing. There's a few tracks that once I hear, Im humming them for the rest of the day. This is such a great game to chill with.

A fun and very intuitive sim game with great performance and clean graphics. There is a ton of content that you gradually unlock throughout the campaign. Each new scenario presents unique challenges to spice things up. Some aspects get repetitive but the game has a strong gameplay loop that will keep completionists busy.

Purchased this game when it was on sale for only a few bucks, thinking I would get maybe a day or two of entertainment before getting bored with what appears to be a very simple game with a very simple premise.

Here I am, weeks later, still playing this game in the small amount of free time I have, and still having a blast.

The music, the "radio DJ's", the art style, all come together beautifully and perfectly around the shockingly complex gameplay.

The desire to chase the first, second, and then last "star" of each campus level scratches the itch for challenge, while the gameplay itself is paradoxically both simplistically relaxing AND complexly stressful. For example, one of the campus levels have students attend your university for free (meaning no constant stream of tuition fees to fill your wallet), instead you get paid a small fee by a 3rd party for every time a student "levels up". The first year of that I was maxed out on loans and still going deeper into the red, unsure if I could ever get out...2 or 3 years later, I was raking in MILLIONS within a single school year.

The gameplay itself at a surface level is indeed very simple. Create a building on this piece of land here, design room layouts inside, give everyone the education requirements and basic needs, click the button to start the next school year and watch it all work itself out. But at the same time, there is so much detail and so many events that require your attention, and by the time your campus really and truly is a "self sustaining" powerhouse, it means you are moments away from getting that final "star" and completing the level, so prepare for the next campus challenge lol. Its brilliant.

I actually feel somewhat bad that I picked this wonderful gem up for pennies on the dollar. I am now a big fan of this studio, and plan to purchase their other products after I complete this game. Honestly, I give this game the rare 10/10. I seriously cannot think of a single aspect of playing this game that is an issue. It is a perfect game for exactly what it is.

Yep, love it. Played a lot of hours. It's very organizational. A good chill game to zen out your brain. Developer rocks. All around worth it. Highly recommend. I've played all their stuff and will buy more.
Not too hard relaxing game if you liked Two Point Hospital or the older Theme Hospital

This game has become my relaxation after a stressful and tiring day from work. Its chill, no pressure and its really satisfying.
Just good fun. Runs great as well. I plan on getting the other two games in the series.

Great content! Bought this game during autumn sale for only RM9 (Malaysia currency), didn't even realize its ori orice is RM100!!! Such a great deal. This game is a strategy singleplayer mode where I can use my idea and plan wisely, and honestly it's a perfect type for me who enjoys cozy and mid-challenging game. Will consider to buy Two Point Hospital & Museums as well!
Weirdly enough, quite an enjoyable game, this is my first game of this series, maybe going to play the others, but i quite enjoying it. The radio segments in the game genuinely make me laugh

This game pretty much altered how I perceived reality because when I went to a convention, I saw a staff room and immediately thought 'Needs more paintings. Maybe a plant by the door and some hand sanitizer too.'

Overall, 10/10. Time to play the other titles!!

This one's got it going on. These should be right up my alley but often for one reason or another I end up not coming back. Campus has a great UI and the controller layout lets me do everything in the game. Easy onboarding getting you right in has had me clear two maps and still enjoying it.

Fun game for people who like city builder type games.  The concept is cute / fun.  I like the art / sound / animations.  Very cute / silly.  Easy to relate too.  Game isn't too complex.  I have about 10 hours in and am enjoying it.  Main negative is that the game crashes quite often (once or twice an hour) on my steam deck.  I save a lot and deal with it, but that is annoying.
Overall a nice game. Very similar to the other two-point games and in the same style.

Great game 
I paid ¬£2.49 and it's worth every penny. I have played it before on Xbox 
It works perfectly on steam deck no issues apart from some text is a little hard to read for me.
Everything else is great. Super fun game if you like this type (simulator/tycoon) only played for a while but definitely will be playing it more 
I recommend

I used to play alot of School tycoon when i was a kid, and i was looking for a game similar to it as i missed management and decorative games, and this game is HIM. perfectly what i was looking for, i don't mind if it's just decorate until you win, that's the whole point of this game for me, just decorate my own vision and my own way a campus is what i was looking for

This game is so great. There is so much content and little easter eggs connecting it to Hospital and Museum. These are genuinely my favourite games of all time. Two Point Studios I love you so dearly please never leave us.
I remember playing on my XBOX during 2023 or so, and now this is my first time playing it on Steam! Very fun game in my opinion.

negative.review:
I can‚Äôt recommend this for one reason: The game corrupted my save file and I lost my 26 hour playthrough. And I actually wouldn‚Äôt have minded starting over if the game kept track of all my unlocks. But no. It‚Äôs a complete fresh start and I can‚Äôt even skip the tutorial the second time round. Cloud save is corrupted too. Im sorry but this is unforgivable. Can‚Äôt even remember the last time this happened to a save file in a game. Maybe on the original PlayStation with a damaged memory card? 

Sucks cause I was really enjoying the game until this.

I cannot recommend this game. It is fun to play, but support is non-existent. The game disconnected me from the two point site and will not reconnect. Support has not helped after contacting repeatedly.

Prefiro o Two Point Hospital ent√£o se eu tivesse que recomendar seria ele. S√≥ recomendo o Campus pra quem gosta MUITO do Two Point Hospital e quer ter novas experiencias de gameplay em um jogo semelhante.
very buugy
mom

What happened to investing real effort into games instead of just shifting the theme in a second? Honestly, Two Point Campus feels like a recycled version of Two Point Hospital. So much of the design, the aesthetics, and the in-game items seem directly carried over, and it‚Äôs really disappointing.
I bought Two Point Hospital along with all its expansion packs, and I was excited to see what changes and improvements this new title would bring. But instead of fresh aesthetics, challenges, or innovative features, it feels almost identical. After more than three years, the game only has three DLCs, and none of them bring meaningful additions.

In Two Point Museum they solved so many problems that exist in this game. Unlike Museum, Campus looks inexorably ugly and rewards/demands hideous decoration. All objects are too large and cramp the rooms. Training staff takes forever.

Dealing with a schedule is fun, but it's not involved.

They're different games, but Two Point Museum is just so much better. It's playable with a controller, at least! But so is Museum.

Pretty meh on all levels. I love sims, management games, and builders. However, this one feels shallow on all fronts. Not an enjoyable experience and has really turned me off of the Two Point formula.

I can‚Äôt recommend this for one reason: The game corrupted my save file and I lost my 26 hour playthrough. And I actually wouldn‚Äôt have minded starting over if the game kept track of all my unlocks. But no. It‚Äôs a complete fresh start and I can‚Äôt even skip the tutorial the second time round. Cloud save is corrupted too. Im sorry but this is unforgivable. Can‚Äôt even remember the last time this happened to a save file in a game. Maybe on the original PlayStation with a damaged memory card? 

Sucks cause I was really enjoying the game until this.

Too simple, too boring.

There is no challenge, you just build rooms and add decorations until you win. That's it. 

You don't have to juggle a queue like in Hospital, or make it more efficient to handle a larger visitor number. You just build, watch, then win.

I cannot recommend this game. It is fun to play, but support is non-existent. The game disconnected me from the two point site and will not reconnect. Support has not helped after contacting repeatedly.

I'm very glad I got this game for only $3. And I don't think it was even worth that. This is a franchise that is stuck and just isn't evolving. There's no gameplay. Nothing you do feels like it matters. The interface is the clunkiest it's ever been.

The game seems to have a lot of content and features, but they don't come together into a cohesive whole. The game feels super simplistic, and the gameplay loop doesn't feel rewarding or interesting at any point

Prefiro o Two Point Hospital ent√£o se eu tivesse que recomendar seria ele. S√≥ recomendo o Campus pra quem gosta MUITO do Two Point Hospital e quer ter novas experiencias de gameplay em um jogo semelhante.

this game was my first introduction to the two point series, and although i did love it at the time, ive since platinumed museum and it just does not compare. most of the "gameplay" in campus is just waiting for the school year to end and it feels like an idle game. the objectives are not very fun or rewarding, and im simply playing just to beat it. i will always love this game since it introduced me to museum which has become one of my favorite games of all time, but i would recommend skipping this.

Super Casual. You can't loose. I'm not really a try hard in general asking for crazy difficulty, but a game needs three things :
Rules, a way(s) to win, a way(s) to loose. If you can only win, it's not a game.
this game is sooo mf buggy! couldn't even get through the second level, save your time and money and purchase another game...
Boring. Easy. Low replayability chance. It is not worth more than 5 euros.

No, just no. Not fun, Lots of things breaks immersion.
Do not support this studio. The main reason is due to a charity this studio supports. The charity is called "Mermaids", just Google what that is, a hint it has to do with an ideology and kids.

I placed hand sanitizers, showers, hired tons of janitors, put TONS OF TRASH CANS
and my students, STILL WON'T SHOWER
0/10 accurate to real life league of legends player behavior

I like the game concept but this games fails in the first 30 min.

I don't like forced tutorials.

I often just start playing and most of the times I get how the game is supposed to be played and sure sometimes I'm lost and I go back and do play the tutorial but this game is easy I've played many room building games and I just want to have some sandbox fun and make some random stuff but damn this is annoying and boring just let me fail horribly instead of hand holding this badly.
very buugy
mom

Sucks cause I was really enjoying the game until this.

Pretty meh on all levels. I love sims, management games, and builders. However, this one feels shallow on all fronts. Not an enjoyable experience and has really turned me off of the Two Point formula.

Too simple, too boring.

There is no challenge, you just build rooms and add decorations until you win. That's it. 

You don't have to juggle a queue like in Hospital, or make it more efficient to handle a larger visitor number. You just build, watch, then win.

If you expect to build and manage mega or at least big scale university, you better get another game. You cant build second floor in this game, yes you read it right, Campus management without any second floor, you dont manage a campus,you manage a small town high school, it's fun if you want to manage a high school or simple small campus, otherwise dont buy it
